Chris, by 'overrides the normal trim' do you mean that the WorkbenchWindow doesn't use TrimLayout? If so where does the FastViewBar appear?

Have you turned off FastViews?

I just had a meeting with Boris regarding RCP compatibility issues; I guess that this is the first of a few...;-(.

Committed in >20070329. Added a safety check in case there is no FastViewManager. If we aren't using the TrimLayout it's null...

Chris, I haven't tested this because I'm unsure of the scenario that you're actually using. It should certainly get rid of the NPE but other issues may arise. If you can send me a snippet or explanation of the setup I can try to repro it here (or you can try tomorrow's build and let me know...;-). In either case I'll leave it open until I can verify that I've covered all bases...
Hi Eric,

The root of the problem is that we are overriding WorkbenchWindowAdvisor#createWindowContents.  We creating an entirely custom branded RCP.  We are not creating the fastview bars.  As far as I can tell, if I'm overriding createWindowContents theres no way for me to create the fastview bars.  IWorkbenchWindowConfigurer has a variety of createXXX methods but none for the fastview bars (not sure if it would even make sense for it to).  

Chris, I'm fairly sure that your particualr case should be covered by tomorrow's I-build. It should no longer use the new min/max behavior if the layout being used is not the default 'TrimLayout' (which it isn't in your case is it?).

If you're in a position to do so it'd be most appreciated if you could test it and gt back with any problems...thanks.

Rats! Committed in >20070411. Wire off the case where the perspective's FVM is null.

Chris, is there a short(ish) RCP snippet that you can give me that'll show this? Anything that sets up the WorkbenchWindow the way that you're using it would give me a nice starting testbed...(so I can find the rest of the errors rather than putting you through the mill...;-).
You can use the same projects I'm using.  The RCP is an example app that I'm working on for Nebula so its not really complicated.  It also uses a custom presentation, but that may not be necessary to repro any of the problems.  I've commented out the line that sets the preference value to that custom presentation.  You can comment it back in to test that part.  Its line 27 of the ApplicationWorkbenchAdvisor.  I'm attaching both the rcp app project and the presentation project.
Created an attachment (id=63506)
RCP app project

Created an attachment (id=63507)
Presentation project

Does all this mean that if I write my own custom presentation and have my own custom trim, that I wont be able to reproduce the kind of presentation now default in 3.3?  For this Nebula stuff it doesn't matter but my actual IBM project we'd like to do that.  Essentially copy the pattern and behavior in the presentation but we have to rebrand everything.  So we need a custom trim and a custom presentation.  

Chris, thanks for the quick response...

If you want the new 'min' behavior then at minimum we need to use the 'standard' workbenchwindow 'TrimLayout' as the layout for the window (it manages IWindowTrim elements...which is what the minimized stacks ultimately are...).

Note that you can contribute 'custom' trim into a standard presentation using the 'org.eclipse.ui.menus' extension point. Essentially you contribute a 'toolbar' to one of the trim areas and contribute a 'control' to it...
Our custom branding requirements go waay beyond just adding a toolbar.  Thats why we override createContents.  It seems kinda cruddy that we lose the new behavior.  Maybe that can be addressed post 3.3.

Thanks Chris, I'll set up the samples you supplied and use them for my first cut at managing custom presentations.

Post 3.3 we're going to be comletely reviewing the presentation implementation...

I'll make sure that the scenario of replacing the 'innards' (the center composite left over after the trim has been arranged) independently from managing the 'trim' is covered in our discussions.

Chris, since the NPE is gone (AFAIK) I'm going to mark this as FIXED. If you're still having issues using this week's I-build then feel free to re-open.

The ideas for teh separation of the 'innards' vs the 'trim' are caprured in my notebook for our design discussions for post-3.3.
Sounds good.

Verified (visually) in I20070501-0010.
